benchmark_details.name: LLM vs. Lawyers: Identifying a Subset of Summary Judgments in a Large UK Case Law Dataset
benchmark_details.overview: This study introduces a methodology for identifying summary judgment cases from the Cambridge Law Corpus using two computational methods: a traditional NLP approach and a large language model (LLM), effectively demonstrating the utility of NLP technologies in legal research.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To accurately identify summary judgment cases within a large corpus of UK court decisions to support legal research.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: This study may not encompass all summary judgments delivered by the courts.

data.annotation: Manually reviewed and identified by legal experts and analyzed using computational methods.

methodology.calculation: F1 Score calculated for each method based on precision and recall.
methodology.interpretation: An F1 Score closer to 1 indicates better classification performance.
methodology.baseline_results: Traditional NLP based approach achieved an F1 score of 0.78; LLM approach achieved an F1 score of 0.94.
methodology.validation: Manual review of sampled data to ensure accurate identification of summary judgment cases.

harm: Potential misclassification of non-summary judgment cases
